channel.title: number_theory on Ben Clingenpeel
channel.description: Recent content in number_theory on Ben Clingenpeel

item.title: Euler's totient function
item.description: Definitions Eulerâ€™s totient function is a function \(\phi: \N \to \N\) such that \(\phi(n)\) is the number of numbers that are less than or equal to \(n\) and relatively prime to \(n\). That is, \[\phi(n) = \# \{m \in \N \mid m \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(m,n) = 1\}.\] Properties If \(p\) is a prime number, then \(\phi(p) = p-1\) because every natural number less than or equal to \(p\) is relatively prime to it except \(p\) itself.

item.title: Coprime numbers
item.description: Definition Two numbers \(a,b \in \N\) are said to be coprime or relatively prime if their greatest common divisor is 1. Properties Because the gcd of two numbers \(a\) and \(b\) can always be written as an integral linear combination of \(a\) and \(b\), there always exist \(s,t \in \Z\) such that \(as + bt = 1\) if and only if \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime.
